repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Emergency Transport and
            Infrastructure Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Transport and
            Infrastructure Development Project for Sudan were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was substantial; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and grantee performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            flow of funds from the government for road maintenance had
            to compete with emergency and security road construction and
            other government priorities. Road maintenance had always
            been minimal compared to the need. The project has greatly
            contributed to addressing the principal challenge of
            capacity limitation to deliver results in the post conflict
            and newly emerging country. Further, training of staff only
            by itself is not adequate in building institutional capacity
            and it appears that direct engagement of staff during
            procurement and contract management processes in the form of
            on the job training is essential. The capacity of the
            construction industry in South Sudan was very low during
            project preparation and implementation. All contracted firms
            were foreign and often hired workers from outside the
            country. Lessons emerging from other places suggest
            including some maintenance funding in the project to ensure
            sustainability in medium term. The project experienced
            massive claims under component two due to delays affected by
            externalities indifferent to project activities, weak
            reporting structures, and inexperience of the implementing
            agencies. In order to avoid underrating the outcome of the
            project, the formulation of the results framework should
            have attempted to include specific objectives for each phase
            rather than establish a general Project Development
            Objective (PDO) for the whole project.

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Emergency Transport and
            Infrastructure Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Emergency Transport and Infrastructure Development Project
            is to rehabilitate and develop critical national and rural
            feeder roads and transport infrastructure, improve critical
            urban infrastructure in the major towns that form the
            national and state capitals of Southern Sudan and build
            capacity for planning, construction and sustainable
            operation, maintenance and management of the infrastructure
            in Southern Sudan. The closing date for the project will be
            extended from June 30, 2011 until June 30, 2012. The
            extension is necessary to: (i) complete the claims
            assessment and prepare final account, including
            compensations; (ii) conduct claims settlement negotiations;
            and (iii) engage consultants that will support the
            implementing institutions in conducting negotiations and
            additional claims review, as required. The recipient has
            submitted an acceptable implementation plan to complete the
            outstanding activities within the proposed closing date of
            June 30, 2012.

12858321.trustfund:
TF056051-EMERGENCY TRANSPORT AND

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Emergency Transport and
            Infrastructure Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Emergency Transport and Infrastructure Development Project
            is to rehabilitate and develop critical national and rural
            feeder roads and transport infrastructure, improve critical
            urban infrastructure in the major towns that form the
            national and state capitals of Southern Sudan and build
            capacity for planning, construction and sustainable
            operation, maintenance and management of the infrastructure
            in Southern Sudan. The extension is necessary to: 1)
            complete the feeder roads study that was interrupted due to
            in securities in some of the project areas; 2) extend the
            sealing works on limited critical sections (about 6 to 7 km)
            of the Farksika-Yambio road to avoid premature failure of
            the road and reduce health and safety hazards, with the
            savings from the road contracts; 3) resolve outstanding
            claims related to the Emergency Rehabilitation Works in Juba
            (ERWJ); and 4) to continue with  the provision of training
            and Technical Assistance (TA) services to further strengthen
            implementation capacity. The closing date of the project
            will be extended from December 30, 2010 until June 30, 2011.
            This will be the first extension of the project.
